title: How to increase my vocabulary through books, etc - Quora

response.answer_text: I might be wrong, but isn't the question the answer?You don't have to be exceptionally good at reading to learn from books. I mean, if you love to read, then pick up a particularly long book, or one made for older ages, and you'll undoubtedly see words you don't know. You can look them up, or figure them out through context. Just reading IS good enough to learn new words. I have read the dictionary. I learned like, 2 words that I still remember. But from reading books that I love I've learned to spell many words, and learned the meaning of many others.True story, in 9th grade my English class was asked to spell the word doubt, on the whiteboard. Every person in the class tried and failed. The teacher went up and down the rows. Nobody could do it. Then I came in from the bathroom, they asked me, and I spelled it easily. I'd seen it so many times in books. Just reading is good enough for expanding your vocabulary.

Read lots of books that are meant for learners of the language in question. The way these books use restricted and repeated vocabulary in context is one of the more enjoyable and effective ways to learn new words and phrases. Make sure the book is already mostly comprehensible to you (like 95%). That way you can go along with the flow without having to look up words all the time, and the few new words should be more easily picked up and retained. Too many new words might result in your retaining little to nothing at all. Of course, different people have different capacities for learning new vocabulary. If you’re very good at it, you could probably get away with books of which you understand less than 95% and still learn while enjoying the story. In any case, I recommend reading easier books extensively rather than slowly slogging your way through just one really difficult book. Research suggests this is more effective. Huffman, Jeffrey. (2014). Reading rate gains during a one-semester extensive reading course https://wgu.idm.oclc.org/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=eue&AN=99203359&site=eds-live&scope=site

Competely agree with the other two answers- read, read, read, read, read! When you come across a word you don't know or of which you are unsure, try not to disrupt your reading (especially if it is fiction or something that you are reading for pleasure) and read on, but at the end of the chapter, or period of reading, go back to the words you were of which you were unsure and look them up in a dictionary. If you just look them up, whilst they will make sense to you at the time, they will inevitably fade from your memory. Instead- as you look up each word, write it down in a sentence or say it out loud in a sentence or two- you will be surprised at how quickly you expand your vocabulary (understanding) and vocabulary (useage). Endeavour to read everything and anything you can- persevere! Many, many books that have become personal favourites were books that I initially had trouble getting into. Good luck!

A2A 56 years ago, a SF author Robert Anson Heinlein coined a new verb — “to grok”. “Grokking”, — to paraphrase an explanation given by one of the book’s characters — “basically means “drinking”. It’s understanding the things so fully, that they’ll become a part of you.” To increase your vocabulary, you need to grok the words — remembering a list would not do. My suggestion is — read, and then write. Write down your favorite quote and why it’s a favorite. Write down what you felt when you read the book, what you liked and what made you mad. Write a fanfic. Grok the book, make it a part of yourself. When you’d be able to think about the characters in their language, you’d know that you are moving in the right direction.

These days, with the internet, it’s easy to look up every word that you don’t know. So every time you come across a word you don’t fully understand the meaning of—look it up. See if there’s a synonym for the word that you tend to use more often and try to use the new word instead. Keep a list of these words that you come across and pick a ‘word of the day.” Try to use it in a real sentence in a real conversation spoken or written to help get the word into your everyday usage. If you are finding the books you are reading are too easy with very few words you don’t know, challenge yourself with something that is more difficult to read. I think I learned the most new words when I was reading Anthony Burgess. I actually wrote in the margins on my copy of One Hand Clapping. I circled words I didn’t know and wrote brief definitions in the margins.

You already have some excellent answers here. I have thought about this a lot, and the only suggestion I can add is this: If you have already tried reading, and yes, grokking the author’s true intentions as you read, and you have tried vocabulary building books and found them boring, then try puzzle books. There are crosswords, word searches, codewords and varioius other word puzzles to suit all abilities from those designed for children to very challenging cryptic crosswords. That way you can have a bit of fun, learn some new words or get practise with ones you already know, and set yourself a time goal to complete it in order to measure your improvement.

Anytime you read and don’t understand a word, write it down on a sheet of paper. Then look up the word. Once you know what the word means, try to come up with a synonym (another word that means the same thing). Then go back to the original sentence that the word was in and replace it with the new word. Re-read that sentence with the new word. On the sheet of paper you wrote the word down also include the definition and the synonym. Do this for every word you don’t know. You’ll end up with  a good list of vocabulary words to look over periodically and, overtime, you’ll have memorized the definitions and your overall vocabulary should improve.

Well, generally you just need to continue to read all kinds of books that pique your interest. Just ensure that English in the book is good. May be look at best sellers lists. If you are a regular reader, and able to develop a taste in reading (fiction, specially), many benefits come your way: A) subconsciously your vocabulary will improve. You will naturally start using words in the right context. B) your choice of reading and selecting books will improve. This is the only slow and sure way of developing long-lasting vocabulary.

How can I increase my vocabulary through books, etc? Do not try to learn vocabulary. Just read. Read what you enjoy reading. You will automatically increase your vocabulary. I have always loved reading, and within the context of what I read, the definitions of the words I was not yet familiar with became clear. I did not even realize I was increasing my vocabulary. Thanks for the A2A.
